verdict.summary: The compiler cannot resolve a symbol (variable, method, class, or package). Typically caused by typos, missing imports, missing dependencies, or incorrect classpath configuration.

dead_ends.action: Casting the variable to Object or using raw types to suppress the error
dead_ends.why_fails: The symbol is genuinely missing from the compilation classpath. Casting to Object does not make a nonexistent class or method available and will cause ClassCastException or further errors at runtime.
@SuppressWarnings has no effect on compilation errors — it only suppresses warnings. The 'cannot find symbol' error will still prevent compilation.

workarounds.action: Check the import statements and ensure the referenced class or method is imported from the correct package
workarounds.how: 1. Read the compiler error carefully — it tells you the symbol name and the location. 2. Check if the import statement is present and correct. 3. Verify the class/method name spelling. 4. If the symbol is from a dependency, verify the dependency is declared in pom.xml or build.gradle. 5. Run 'mvn clean compile' or 'gradle clean build' to ensure all dependencies are resolved.

workarounds.action: Verify the dependency containing the symbol is on the compilation classpath
workarounds.how: 1. Identify which library provides the missing symbol. 2. Check if it is declared in your build file (pom.xml / build.gradle). 3. Verify the dependency scope — 'provided' or 'test' scope dependencies are not available during main compilation. 4. Run 'mvn dependency:resolve' or check Gradle's dependency report. 5. If using a multi-module project, ensure the module dependency is declared.
workarounds.condition: when the symbol is from an external library

leads_to.condition: when the symbol is found at compile time but the class is missing at runtime due to scope mismatch

preceded_by.condition: when a dependency conflict excludes the JAR containing the needed symbol

frequently_confused_with.distinction: cannot find symbol is a compile-time error; ClassNotFoundException is a runtime error when the JVM cannot locate a class
